I've lost 170 lbs and kept it off for 10 years! I love cooking and making as many things homemade as I possibly can! I'm obsessed with my ginger tabby cat. Did I mention I love music? I LOVE MUSIC!

summary: “All the Peppers” Instapot Turkey Chili spicy, smoky protein bomb ~Recipe 3 lbs lean ground turkey 2 poblanos, diced 1-2...
caption:
“All the Peppers” Instapot Turkey Chili

spicy, smoky protein bomb

~Recipe

  • 3 lbs lean ground turkey
  • 2 poblanos, diced
  • 1-2 habaneros, minced (use gloves, for the love of God)
  • 2 red bell peppers, diced
  • 1 medium onion, diced
  • 3 cloves of garlic, minced
  • 2, 28oz cans of crushed tomatoes (preferably no salt added)
  • 1, 15oz can of fire roasted tomatoes
  • 4 TBSP tomato paste
  • ½ TBSP honey
  • ¼ cup apple cider vinegar
  • 2 TBSP ancho chili powder
  • 1 TBSP chipotle chili powder
  • note–go ahead and sub regular chili powder if it’s what you got, I’m just fuckin’ bougie with spices
  • 1 TBSP smoked paprika
  • 1 TBSP cumin
  • 1 tsp Mexican oregano
  • 1 ½ tsp salt (adjusted if tomatoes are salted)
  • ½ tsp black pepper
  • ½ tsp chili flake

~Directions

  1. Prepare all vegetables, set aside.
  2. Set your Instapot to the saute setting, spray with no-stick, and brown the meat after it has heated.
  3. Add in the spices, stir to combine. Add in the vinegar, stir to combine. Add in the vegetables, stir to combine. Add in the tomatoes and tomato paste, stir to combine. Add in the honey, stir to combine.
  4. Set your Instapot to the slow cooking setting and slow cook for about 4:30 hours, until vegetables are tender. The “more” setting can be used if chili is desired sooner.

~Macros

Approximately 13g of fat, 25g of carbohydrates, and 31g of protein

~A significant source of

fiber, vitamins A, C, E, B1, B2, B3, B5, B6, B12, copper, iron, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, potassium, selenium, and zinc

*based on my preparations and portion size

Substitutions 

  1. Any other chili can be used in place of habanero if that’s just too much, man.
  2. Use a combination of beans in place of the turkey if the meat is just not your thing. Be aware there will likely be significant changes to the cooking time. Agave or another sugar can be used if you want a vegan conversion.

summary: Dia de #TBT... De GG pra M. Engraçado que não me sentia quase 29kg mais gordo, acho que só caiu a ficha quando resolvi cuidar da...
caption:
Dia de #TBT… De GG pra M. Engraçado que não me sentia quase 29kg mais gordo, acho que só caiu a ficha quando resolvi cuidar da saúde mesmo, aí sim fui ver os benefícios da mudança. A estética é legal? De certa forma sim, mas o mais importante é a saúde, disposição, vontade de fazer as coisas. Por isso eu digo, me sinto fisicamente mais disposto que a 10 anos. Então nunca pense que é tarde, da tempo e sobra pra vc correr atrás. Só tenha calma e perseverança.
.

summary: Book Review: You Have The Right To Remain Fat
title: Book Review: You Have The Right To Remain Fat
body:
Book Review: You Have The Right To Remain Fat

You Have The Right To Remain Fat
by Virgie Tovar
Nonfiction
128 pages
Published 2018

You Have The Right To Remain Fat is a short manifesto on why society needs to change the way it treats fat people, and that we don’t need to lose weight to fit into society. Tovar talks about the sexism, classism, and racism that is often behind fatphobia and discrimination, the way culture has shifted around…

View On WordPress

blog.name: puppyexpressions
blog.title: Puppy Expressions
blog.description: Welcome to the world of dogs.

summary: 5 Common Causes of Hair Loss in Dogs
title: 5 Common Causes of Hair Loss in Dogs
body:
What’s Causing the Dog Hair Loss?

Seeing a dog lose his or her hair can be disconcerting to witness. However, what’s most important when dealing with alopecia, as it is referred to medically, is identifying the underlying cause of the hair loss in order to devise an appropriate treatment plan. Here are five common culprits of hair loss in dogs that should be discussed with your veterinarian.

1. Allergies

Allergies are a frequent cause of hair loss in dogs. This may due to environmental triggers such as pollen, molds and dust mites, or due to parasitic triggers like fleas or mites. Food allergies are another possible cause of hair loss. Typical symptoms of an adverse allergic reaction include itchiness resulting in excess scratching, biting, and, of course, hair loss. In the case of flea allergies, it is recommended that dogs take flea preventatives as a way to minimize threats of a full-blown flea infestation.

2. Infection or Infestation

An infestation with parasites such as fleas, ticks, and mites (scabies, mange) is another source canine alopecia. Along with hair loss around the ears, eyes, abdomen, and chest, signs your dog may have mites or fleas/ticks include inflammation, itching and redness. Bacterial or fungal infections, such as in the case of ringworm (which is actually a fungus), can also be attributed to hair loss in dogs. Symptoms of ringworm include circular or irregular hair loss, inflammation, and infected crusts.

3. Cushing’s Disease

Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing’s disease, is a condition caused by the prolonged exposure of the body’s tissue to excessive levels of the hormone cortisol. Symptoms of Cushing’s disease include hair loss, darkening of the skin, and the development of a pot-bellied abdomen. Cushing’s disease commonly occurs in middle-aged to senior dogs, though it can also affect dogs that overuse corticosteroid drugs.

4. Genetics

There are some breeds of dog that are more genetically prone to baldness than others. First there are the hairless dogs that have been bred for the attribute such as the Chinese Crested, Mexican Hairless (Xolo), and American Hairless Terrier. Other dog breeds, such as the Doberman Pinscher, Dachshund, Chihuahua, Italian Greyhound and Whippet, sometimes suffer from patchy or pattern baldness on the outer ear, chest, back, thigh, or lower neck.

5. Pressure Sores

Pressure sores, also called bedsores or decubital ulcers, are localized injuries where the dog’s elbows or other bony pressure points (hips, hocks, etc.) come into contact with hard surfaces regularly. This constant pressure and friction causes the skin to callus, lose hair and sometimes crack and bleed. Pressure sores are more common older dogs, especially large or heavy breeds.

reblog.comment:
What’s Causing the Dog Hair Loss?

Seeing a dog lose his or her hair can be disconcerting to witness. However, what’s most important when dealing with alopecia, as it is referred to medically, is identifying the underlying cause of the hair loss in order to devise an appropriate treatment plan. Here are five common culprits of hair loss in dogs that should be discussed with your veterinarian.

1. Allergies

Allergies are a frequent cause of hair loss in dogs. This may due to environmental triggers such as pollen, molds and dust mites, or due to parasitic triggers like fleas or mites. Food allergies are another possible cause of hair loss. Typical symptoms of an adverse allergic reaction include itchiness resulting in excess scratching, biting, and, of course, hair loss. In the case of flea allergies, it is recommended that dogs take flea preventatives as a way to minimize threats of a full-blown flea infestation.

2. Infection or Infestation

An infestation with parasites such as fleas, ticks, and mites (scabies, mange) is another source canine alopecia. Along with hair loss around the ears, eyes, abdomen, and chest, signs your dog may have mites or fleas/ticks include inflammation, itching and redness. Bacterial or fungal infections, such as in the case of ringworm (which is actually a fungus), can also be attributed to hair loss in dogs. Symptoms of ringworm include circular or irregular hair loss, inflammation, and infected crusts.

3. Cushing’s Disease

Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing’s disease, is a condition caused by the prolonged exposure of the body’s tissue to excessive levels of the hormone cortisol. Symptoms of Cushing’s disease include hair loss, darkening of the skin, and the development of a pot-bellied abdomen. Cushing’s disease commonly occurs in middle-aged to senior dogs, though it can also affect dogs that overuse corticosteroid drugs.

4. Genetics

There are some breeds of dog that are more genetically prone to baldness than others. First there are the hairless dogs that have been bred for the attribute such as the Chinese Crested, Mexican Hairless (Xolo), and American Hairless Terrier. Other dog breeds, such as the Doberman Pinscher, Dachshund, Chihuahua, Italian Greyhound and Whippet, sometimes suffer from patchy or pattern baldness on the outer ear, chest, back, thigh, or lower neck.

5. Pressure Sores

Pressure sores, also called bedsores or decubital ulcers, are localized injuries where the dog’s elbows or other bony pressure points (hips, hocks, etc.) come into contact with hard surfaces regularly. This constant pressure and friction causes the skin to callus, lose hair and sometimes crack and bleed. Pressure sores are more common older dogs, especially large or heavy breeds.

Weights Before Cardio: Stop Working Against Yourself
